ratings.comment: No lecture slides or even outlines. Just opens the book and starts to talk. He's not exciting, but if you want to take a class with a draconian attendance policy with a professor who incessantly utters 'as it were' and makes very unclear tangents, take something with Loewenstein.
Dull and uninspiring.

Perhaps not the most exciting lecturer, but he really has a passion for his craft. Take notes on: key terms, characters, and places. The TA's grading on papers are difficult, so attend office hours and get them peer edited for better results.

Horrible class.  Although prof knows the subject, he just rambles with no clear outline or lesson plan.  Exams were really easy.  Dis was hard; TA graded papers way too tough for a 100 level class.  DO NOT TAKE JACOB T. AS A TA!!  With a decent TA would be an ok class.
Lectures were semi helpfu l because the only importance were the few words he put on the board. Exams were easy but the TA grade the papers too hard.

One of the most engaging, passionate, and most knowledgable professors I've had at UW. Knows everything about English literature, especially the icons of 17th c. lit. Getting an A isn't too hard if you put a slight amount of effort into the papers. Can't understate this man's passion for the course material.

Great class. Lectures helpful, but I skipped quite a few and was fine. Exams are beyond easy; papers depend on your TA. Lowenstein is great, interesting, and passionate about the literature, but you don't need his interpretation to do well in the class. Easy A if you do the work.

Cool guy! He does repeat himself a lot (usually makes only a couple big points per lecture) but insightful and a good Lit.req class (if you have interest in Shakes.) Class DEFINITELY depends on TA, mine was easy-going and didn't assign weekly hw (some do) and they are pretty hard graders for essays. Tests aren't bad if you go to lecture / review.

This guy gets such a bad rep on here and he doesn't deserve it. Sure, he stutters and repeats himself sometimes, but it's not really distracting. Also, despite this class being populated by some 300 students, he is incredibly nice and willing to help students on a personal, one-to-one level. He injects humor into his lectures, which is a nice touch

His lectures are interesting because he knows a lot about Shakespeare, yet it's sometimes hard not to doze off during them. It's not crucial you go to lecture, but it's helpful for when you have to write papers and the tests. Easiness depends on the TA, mine was really good and fair but I heard a few others might be harder

Dr. L was very redundant, his lectures were not linear in anyway-he kept bouncing around. It was hard to follow and at the end of lecture I'd realize he made one point the entire time. My TA was a hard grader and expected too much for a 100 level course. I was excited to take the class, but he ruined it for me. Do not take Eng162 with Lowenstein!

He gets really into Shakespeare, and knows what he is talking about. He repeats a lot during lecture, and I often find myself zoning out a lot. Sometimes he makes jokes, but overall an enjoyable class. It really depends on your TA though

He gets really into Shakespeare, and knows what he is talking about. He repeats a lot during lecture, and I often find myself zoning out a lot. Sometimes he makes jokes, but overall an enjoyable class. It really depends on your TA though

Comment below says "tests were easy" and "spark notes are fine"...What an idiot. listen guys.  Loewenstein's classes are great if you like to learn and read.  If not, study business or something.  Go home and wait tables.

He has a bad reputation for his public speaking skills (or lack thereof), but I took a very small honors section with him, and it wasn't at all a problem in a more discussion-style setting. The subject matter (John Milton) was a little daunting, but he is incredibly knowledgeable and did an impressive job making dry 17th-century lit interesting.

I was skeptical at first because his reviews aren't highly complimentary (get over the stuttering already!), but Loewenstein is EXTREMELY knowledgeable, clear, and devoted--I got something useful out of every lecture and was able to apply everything directly to the exams. If you're familiar with the text and listen carefully in lecture, you're set.

This professor is great.  I thought he did a great job at giving us a balanced introduction to Shakespeare--background, interpretation, and analysis.  He speaks passionately about the drama, and this passion is contagious.

hard to listen too with all the "uh" and "as it were" constantly.  but hey he's a shakespeare prof...don't they all talk like that?  fair tests...really just depends on your TA.  if you can't do it, you don't really need to read all the plays, but it helps make lectures less boring

Tests were easy.  I got screwed over because of my TA. Lectures are involved and hard to sit through, BUT you can basically memorize word for word what he says in lectures and apply it straight to the tests. Spark notes work fine.

Stuttering aside, not incredibly intersting, but a good class in itself. Its all pretty straightforward, but his stuttering can be distracting at times. its true, and unavoidable, really. Just try not to laugh when he does it. Good at explaining shakespeare though, so...who cares about other stuff?
I enjoyed his class!

Awful. A man who lectures for a living should know how to speak. The class is easy; simply reading the material will be sufficient to do well in the class, which is good, because the lectures are insufferable.
No Comments

Dude can not give a lecture to save his life.  His vocabulary usually consists of mostly "Uh"s and "Um"s.  Easy course though, and I didn't even bother sitting through lecture most of the time.  I got more out of the Spark Notes than his lectures.

He seems like a very nice person, but as previously stated he needs to take a public speaking class.  The same phrases being repeated over and over puts you to sleep and the meticulous analyzing of every passage in a play is extremely tiring.  Nice and easy overall, but the class does not inspire.

He knows what he is talking about and not a hardass at all... he ties in material very nicely... kind of boring though, talks about the same thing for about 20 minutes and it could be summed up into 5 or 10
This man said um/ah 360 times in 40 minutes.
He stutters and says ummm and uh alot.  Can be distracting.Tests aren't too bad.
He stutters and he's not very interesting--can be an annoyance
brings in lots of sources other than the text to relate the reading to different authors and sources for Shakespeare's works
As has been stated, he overuses vocalized pauses.  However, I think that gets better as the class goes on and he becomes more comfortable.  Super smart, respected nationwide.  Fun class.

I like the fact that he knows what he's talking about and he obviously loves what he does, I just wish he could get out a full sentence without stopping. But, he's more than happy to help anyone who needs it and he cares about his class.
Lectures are extremely boring.  He said Um/Uh 163 times in 11 minutes the second class period.  Very well respected nationwide I hear, though.

Um..Um..Um..Ah..Ah..Ah..Ah..I started to go to class quite a bit, and then I realized that he is boring and you can't follow a word he Ah..says.  After I realized that um..he can't speak very well, I decided not to go anymore, and I still got a good grade
Wastes a lot of time saying "uh, um, uh," in lecture. Fortunately, if you read the material and go to discussion, you can sleep through lectures and still be fine.
teaches tot he course not material. Not all shakespeare is summed up in "theatricality" but if you know how the plays relate to this you can get an A. Easy as pie.
No Comments
He's a good professor but he mostly lectures and lots of people slept through the class.  His papers or tests are not particularly difficult as long as you read the material.
